Electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide to formate via nano-prism assembled CuO microspheres

g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
Nano-prism self-assembly hierarchical CuO microsphere was synthesized. Three-dimensional framework of CuO enlarged electrocatalytic interfaces. Nano-prisms induced strong electric field and facilitated charge transfer process. Faradaic efficiency for formate conversion reached to 65.1%.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 6 June 2019 Received in revised form 3 August 2019 Accepted 5 August 2019 Available online 8 August 2019
Handling Editor: E. Brillas
Keywords: CuO catalyst Nano-prism structure CO2 electroreduction Formate production Electric field intensity
a b s t r a c t
Electrochemical reduction of CO2 has been demonstrated as one of the promising technologies to reduce the greenhouse effect. In this study, nano-prism assembled hierarchical CuO microspheres (Prism-CuO) were designed and used for CO2 electroreduction. The Prism-CuO coated gas diffusion electrode showed high activity for CO2-to-formate conversion with overpotential as low as ~200mV, and achieved maximum faradaic efficiency of 65.1% at 1.6 V vs. Ag/AgCl. Moreover, it maintained the stable performance for continuous 20 h of electrolysis. The better performance was mainly attributed to the unique prism feature as it provided abundant corner- and edge-based low-coordinated active reaction sites. These sites could further arouse strong local-electric field to lower the barrier of CO2 adsorption and motivate CO2 activation by accelerating charges transfer process. The result implied designing the nanoprism constructed hierarchical framework would be an efficient strategy to develop the advanced electrocatalyst for efficient CO2 reduction in aqueous solution.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The increased consumption of fossil fuels and the associated emission of CO2 into the atmosphere have caused severe energy crisis and global warming (Hall-Spencer et al., 2008; Davis et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2014). Since the recognition of these serious
problems, effective methods to convert and recycle CO2 have aroused intense research interest. A promising and attractive route is to electrochemically reduce CO2 into carbon-based value-added chemicals like carbon monoxide, hydrocarbon, carboxylic acid, alcohols, and aldehydes by controlling multiple proton and electron transfer steps (Kuhl et al., 2012). Among all the possible products, formate (HCOO ) or formic acid (HCOOH) is desired owing to their broad application in fuel cells, H2 storage material, syngas conversion, and other industrial feedstock (Zhang et al., 2017). The strategy essentially involves catalyzing the reaction by means of a homogeneous or heterogeneous catalyst (Costentin et al., 2013). Copper, as the most promising catalyst for its capability of selective hydrocarbons production, has attracted great attention among various metal-based electrocatalysts that have been tested (Peterson et al., 2010; Kuhl et al., 2012). However, the previous results indicate that activities of polycrystalline or single-crystal Cu electrode are far from satisfactory (Qiao et al., 2014a). The biggest challenge in CO2 electroreduction is still the sluggish activity of electrocatalysts (Qiao et al., 2014b).
In comparison with using metallic catalysts directly, metal oxides are introduced to prepare oxide-derived Cu (OD-Cu) or CuxO/ Cu (OD-CuxO/Cu) composites for CO2 reduction at reduced potentials (Qiao et al., 2014a;Ma et al., 2015; Dutta et al., 2016; Zhao et al., 2017b). It has been found the onset potential and product selectivity of CO2 electroreduction closely depend on surface properties and structures of OD-Cu because the electrochemical interfaces are regulated by diverse crystal orientation, shape, and particle size (Chen and Kanan, 2012; Li and Kanan, 2012; Tang et al., 2012; Wu et al., 2012; Feng et al., 2015; Verdaguer-Casadevall et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2016). Impressively, the OD-Cu foam after surface reconstruction has three-dimensional open frameworks, abundant grain-boundaries supported active sites, and preferable (100) and (111) facets, which achieves Faradaic efficiency of HCOOH (FEHCOOH) and CO (FECO) ~23% and ~39% at potential of 0.45 V vs. RHE (Reversible Hydrogen Electrode) (Min et al., 2016). Copper rods with the diameter of 100e1000 nm embedded with nanoparticles (20 nm) are successfully formed by reduction of Cu2O layer, and this structure considerably enlarges the electrochemically active surface area so that the FEHCOOH is 40% at an applied potential of 0.5 V vs. RHE (Li and Kanan, 2012). It is noted that higher specific surface area also provides diffusion channels for reactants, therefore explains the excellent performance of the hierarchical CuxO/Cu nanoparticles for CO2 electroreduction (Qiao et al., 2015). Although succeeding efforts have been put into enhancing the electroreduction performance of OD-Cu catalysts, it is easy to find the performance of these OD-Cu based catalysts towards CO2 electroreduction is far from satisfactory in terms of large overpotential, low Faradaic efficiency, and poor selectivity in adequos electrolyte. Therefore, designing robust catalysts still requires further efforts.
Recently, metals with 2D nano-structured catalysts have been proposed to facilitate higher performance for CO2 electroreduction. It has been demonstrated that the catalytic performance of Bi nanosheets is proportional to the number of low-coordinated sites like corners and edges because these sites benefit the production of higher local electric field (Sarfraz et al., 2016; Kim et al., 2017). Similar results of highly selective for CO2 conversion to formate by the 2D vertical-standing BieSnO2 nanosheets also attributes the excellent performance to the unique Sn nanosheets which consist of many edge and corner sites that lead to a strong local electric field (Wen et al., 2018). Inspired by these results, preparing the Cubased microspheres built by corner- and edge-featured structure is expected to improve the performance of CO2 electroreduction.
In this study, nano-prism assembled CuO (Prism-CuO) microspheres were prepared and applied to electrochemically reduce CO2 during which OD-Cu composites were generated. The
performance of such catalysts was evaluated in terms of the onset potential, faradaic efficiency, and durability for formate production. Furthermore, the mechanism of enhanced activities of CO2 electroreduction was discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Catalyst and electrode preparation
sections.text:
Prism-CuO microspheres: Prism-CuO microspheres were synthesized through hydrothermal method (Pan et al., 2011). In a typical process, 6mL of ammonia solution (25%) and 6mL of ethylene glycol were added into 60mL 0.05M Cu(NO3)2$3H2O solution which was mixed with a magnetic blender for 5min. After then, 15mL of 1M NaOH solution was dropped into the precursor solution and such a mixture was then transferred into 100mL of Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclaves, followed by heating at 110 C. To detect the self-assembly process of Prism-CuO microspheres, samples were collected at different reaction times (16, 20, and 24 h). The final products were collected by centrifugation and thoroughly washed with ethanol and deionized water. Then, all the products were dried in vacuum oven at 60 C overnight.
CuO micro-balls: CuO micro-balls were also synthesized by hydrothermal method (Fan et al., 2015) as follows: 1.0 g Cu(NO3)2$3H2O, 0.7 g dicyandiamide and 1 g PVP were dissolved in 50mL water to form a clear blue solution under stirring. Then the solution was sealed into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclaves and maintained at 180 C for 12 h. The collected products were washed with ethanol and deionized water and then dried in vacuum oven at 60 C overnight.
Electrode preparation: the obtained catalyst powder was first mixed with the binder to form catalyst inks and then coated onto a gas diffusion carbon cloth. Specifically, 15mg catalyst was first suspended in 100 mL isopropanol and ultrasonicated for 30min, then 200 mL Nafion solution (10wt%) was added into the above catalyst ink and sonicated for another 30min. Finally, the catalyst ink was evenly loaded layer-by-layer onto a carbon cloth (3 cm 3 cm).

sections.heading: 2.2. Morphological and structural characterization
sections.text: The morphologies of the catalysts were investigated with scanning electron microscope (SEM, S-4700, Hitachi Ltd.), transmission electron microscopy (TEM, H-7650, Hitachi Ltd.), and highresolution TEM (HR-TEM). Raman spectra was conducted using a 532-nm laser with a Renishaw in Via confocal micro-Raman Spectrometer to obtain the chemical structure. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Germany D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer (l¼ 0.154 nm) using Cu Ka source (60 kV and 80mA), the 2q ranged from 10 to 90 at a scan rate of 4 min＿1. The element valence of catalysts before and after electroreduction was measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with a monochromatic Al Ka radiation at 1486.6 eV (XPS, PH1-5700 ESCA system, US).

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrochemical activities
sections.text:
Electrochemical activities were performed in a typical gas-tight H-type cell, the cell consisted of two chambers, with the volume of each chamber ~150 mL and separated with the Nafion 117 proton exchange membrane. The new prepared electrode and an Ag/AgCl reference electrode (saturated 3 M KCl, þ197 mV vs. standard hydrogen electrode) were fixed in one chamber which also had inlet and outlet pipes for gas bubbling and gaseous product collection, while a platinum sheet (1 cm2) as counter electrode was
fixed in another chamber. The electrolyte in both chambers was 0.5M KHCO3 aqueous solution. Before the tests, the electrolyte was purged with pure N2 or CO2 for 1 h, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was operated from 0 to 1.6 V at 10mV s 1. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed at a constant potential of 1.6 V with the frequency range from 100 kHz to 10mHz and amplitude of 10mV, the testing results were fitted with an equivalent circuit to calculate the value of resistance. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out from 0.1 to 0.3 V in N2-saturated 0.1M HClO4 solution with the scan rate varied from 20 to 100mV s 1. By linearly fitting the current density from CV plot with the scan rate, the active surface area was calculated. For elelctrochemical tests, all applied potentials were referenced against Ag/ AgCl electrode. Electrosorption performance of O and OH on the electrodes was investigated by CV scanning (2mV s 1) in N2-saturated 1M KOH. Before the test, electrodes were firstly used to electrochemically reduce CO2 in 0.1M KHCO3 solution at 1.6 V.

sections.heading: 2.4. Electrochemical reduction of CO2 and product analysis
sections.text:
The CO2 reduction was also performed using the H-type cell with controlled potential by a potentiostat (WonATech WMPG 1000, Korea) under ambient pressure at room temperature. Prior to reduction, CO2 was aerated into the electrolyte to remove other gases and maintained at 10mLmin 1 during the reduction. The electrochemical reduction of CO2 was performed at different potentials from 1.0 to 1.7 V vs. Ag/AgCl for 1 h. Gas products were detected by gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 7890B) equipped with two flame ionization detectors. Liquid products (formate) were identified by ion chromatography (IC 6100, Anhui Wayeal) equipped with Dionex IonpacTM AS-11-HC separation column. The Faradaic efficiency of formate (FEformate) was calculated as following:
FEformate ¼ 2nF Q
(1)
where n is the mole of produced formate, 2 is the number of electrons transferred from CO2 to formate, F is Faraday constant of 96485 C mole1, Q is the total charge passed across the cathode during the electrolysis (C).
2.5. Electric field simulation
Electric field intensity on the Prism-CuO nano-prism was simulated with the COMSOLMultiphysics, and the Electric Currents Module was selected with a specific electrode potential. The electric field densities distributed on the Prism-CuO with different prism corner angles (45 e125 ) and edge lengths (30e100 nm) were simulated at the CO2/COOH equilibrium potential of e 0.627 V vs. Ag/AgCl, and the relationship between applied potential and the electric field density was also simulated.

sections.heading: 3.1. Morphology and structure of prepared catalysts
sections.text:
The morphology of nano-prism assembled dandelion-like CuO (Prism-CuO) microspheres was investigated using SEM and TEM. The Prism-CuO showed the hierarchical framework with an average diameter of about 3 mm (Fig. 1a and d). From higher magnification in Fig. 1b and e, it was clearly indicated that these three-dimensional microspheres were built from nano-prisms (55e60 nm) which aligned perpendicularly to the spherical surface, pointing towards a common center (Shin and Liu, 2004). High resolution-TEM (Fig. S1) clearly indicated the well-defined lattice
istribution of nano-prisms. (c) Raman spectra and (f) XRD patterns of the synthesized
fringes of the CuO (111) plane with the average lattice spacing of ~0.23 nm. Based on the collected samples at different hydrothermal times (Fig. S2), Prism-CuO microspheres were constructed starting from abundant nano-rods huddled together with some littery nanoparticles adhered on to form agglomerates skeleton. These rods and particles further grew orderly to become the prism-like structure which was composed of edges and corner after prolonging time to 24 h and finally the hollow microspheres were developed. Although the hollow CuO micro-balls were synthesized with similar size, these balls were characterized of the compact and airtight surface (Fig. S3). The chemical structure of catalysts was first reflected with Raman spectroscopy. Fig. 1c clearly suggested that the CuO phase was obtained with characteristic peaks at 280, 332, and 617 cm 1 for both catalysts (Xu et al., 1999). To further determine the crystal structure of catalyst particles, samples were tested using XRD and the results were shown in Fig. 1f. The crystallographic phase confirmed the monoclinic structure of CuO with no other impurity peaks according to the JCPDS cards No. 48e1548. Besides, the crystal structure of all the catalysts showed an intense (111) facet (2q¼ 38.7 ). It was well demonstrated that the selectivity and activity of CO2 electroreduction showed an exposed-factdependent behavior especially on Cu based catalyst (Min et al., 2016), and the low-index (111) facet has been inferred to weakly bound the intermediates of OCHO* which benefited the production
Fig. 2. (a) Cu 2p spectra of the synthesized Prism-CuO and CuO micro-balls. Cu 2p3/2 spe electrolysis.
of formate (Min et al., 2016). The prepared catalyst powders were coated on gas-diffusion carbon cloth and used to electrochemically reduce CO2 in CO2saturated 0.5M KHCO3 electrolyte during which CuxO/Cu composites were formed. The XPS spectra of Prism-CuO presented the unique characteristic peaks of CuO as the main peak appeared at 933.5 eV and was accompanied by two satellite peaks at 941.3 and 943.8 eV in Cu 2p spectrum (Fig. 2a and b) (Ma et al., 2015), which was in good agreement with the Raman and XRD results. Compared to the status before electrolysis, all Cu (II) peaks diminished and the main peak in Cu 2p3/2 shifted to the lower binding energy of 932.5 eV as shown in Fig. 2c which confirmed the formation of Cu (0) or Cu (I). Since Cu (0) and Cu (I) had similar binding energy, high-resolution XPS spectrum of Cu LMM was performed. Fig. 2d obviously indicated the presence of metallic Cu (0) after electrolysis. These results demonstrated that the CuO/Cu composites were formed which would remarkably facilitate the activation of CO2 molecule.

sections.heading: 3.2. Electrochemical performance
sections.text:
Electrocatalytic activities of CuO-coated electrodes were evaluated in a standard three-electrodes reactor in both N2- and CO2purged 0.5M KHCO3 electrolyte. As shown in linear sweep
ctra of Prism-CuO before (b) and after (c) electrolysis. (d) Cu LMM of Prism-CuO after
voltammetry (LSV) curves, the current density in N2-saturated KHCO3 solution was mainly caused by hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) (Fig. 3a), whereas higher current density was generated in CO2 purged electrolyte because of the participation of CO2 electroreduction. Compared to CuO micro-balls, much higher current density was achieved with the Prism-CuO in the applied potential range. Additionally, the onset potential shifted positively frome 1.2 to e 0.55 V vs. Ag/AgCl (Table S1), indicative of enhanced electrocatalytic activity to initiate the CO2 reduction. The lowered overpotential and increased current were possibly attributed to the unique nanostructured prisms because the sharp corners and edges could extend the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) which could be evaluated through calculating the double layer capacitance (Qiao et al., 2015). Based on the cyclic voltammetry (CV) results (Fig. S4) and the linear plot of current density against scan rate (Fig. 3b), the bare carbon cloth had a lower capacitance of only 63 mF cm 2, the value increased to 956 mF cm 2 after incorporating with the PrismCuO catalysts which presented 2.1 times higher than that of the CuO micro-balls, confirming that more active site was available for CO2 conversion.
To gain a better understanding about how the structure of catalyst affected the electrochemical activity, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out at the constant potential of e 1.6 V to investigate the kinetics of electron transfer processes (Fig. 3c). This potential was chosen because the maximum FEformate was obtained at the potential of 1.6 V, which indicated the better catalytic activity of cathode at this potential.
According to the EIS fitting result by equivalent circuit model (Table S1) (Chung et al., 2016), the ohmic resistance (Rhom) for all samples changed slightly with the average value of 1.4± 0.05U because of the same electrolyte condition and reactor. A significant variation was found with charge transfer resistance (Rct), as the Prism-CuO exhibited lower Rct of 0.6U, 25% lower than that of CuO micro-balls, which indicated the boosted electronic interaction at the reaction interfaces during CO2 electroreduction. Integrating the SEM results with electrochemical analysis, it was noteworthy that the catalytic activity closely depended on the structure of the catalyst. Constructing the catalyst with the secondary structure composed of sharp corners and edges was beneficial to enhancing the local electric fields (Liu et al., 2016; Wen et al., 2018) which aroused higher local Kþ concentration around these sites. The presence of Kþ could reduce the mean square displacement of CO2 relative to the surface (Liu et al., 2016) and then resulted in a highly local concentration of CO2 close to the edge and corner sites (Safaei et al., 2016; Kim et al., 2017). By this way, the barrier to adsorption of CO2 was lowered, facilitating electron transfer to form CO2 e (Kim et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrochemical CO2 reduction
sections.text:
The faradaic efficiency of formate (FEformate) was performed at various potentials from 1.0 to 1.7 V to evaluate the catalytic performance for CO2 reduction (Fig. 4a). The potential-dependent FEformate showed a volcano-type change (Pan et al., 2017), and the
) LSV curves in N2- (dash line) and CO2- (solid line) saturated 0.5M KHCO3 electrolyte at CV plots. (c) EIS plots in CO2-saturated 0.5M KHCO3 electrolyte scanning from 100 KHz n rate of 2mV s 1.
Prism-CuO exhibited higher FEformate compared to that of CuO micro-balls at the tested potential range. Specifically, themaximum FEformate for Prism-CuO was 65.1% obtained at 1.6 V, which exhibited 1.6 times higher than that of CuO balls. Compared to the previously reported OD-Cu based catalysts (Table S2), the performance of Prism-CuO showed a superior performance since the higher FEformatewas obtained but with much lower catalyst loading. However, it was also easy to find that the maximum FEformate was moderate compared to that of Sn-based catalysts/electrodes which varied from 40e90% towards CO2-to-formate conversion (Table S3). By comparison, the better stability of Prism-CuO was obtained when continuously electrolyzed as discussed later. It was worth noting that the formate was generated at even lower overpotential of ~200mV (applied potential of 1.0 V) for Prism-CuO although the FEformate was less than 20%. Whereas no formate was detected until potential reached 1.3 V with CuO micro-balls electrode. It was also noticable that further decreasing potential preferred to the proton reduction rate which finally resulted in declining FEformate (Pan et al., 2017). From Fig. S6, H2 production exhibited the opposite dependence on both electrodes. For Prism-CuO, the faradaic efficiency of H2 (FEH2) declined as electrode potential decreased to 1.2 V and changed slightly until potential lowered than 1.6 V. Similar trend of FEH2 was obtained with CuO electrode but presented much higher FEH2 than that of Prism-CuO, indicating the better selectivity of Prism-CuO electrode towards CO2 reduction.
The potential-dependent selectivity for CO2 electroreduction could be explained as follows: in the lower overpotential region, HER mainly dominated on electrode due to more favorable thermodynamic and kinetic activity compared to CO2 reduction. In the larger overpotential region, HER regained dominance since CO2 electroreduction was limited by the mass transport due to its low concentration in aqueous media (Kim et al., 2014; Gao et al., 2016; Li et al., 2017). On the other hand, the formate production rate increased substantially with potential lowering 1.3 V and reached to 28.4mg L 1 h 1 cm 2 at 1.7 V which was 2.7 times higher than that of CuO balls (Fig. 4b). Partial current densities of formate (jformate) depended on given potential was plotted in Fig. 4c. The jformate increased remarkably at a more negative potential with both electrodes whereas the jformate of Prism-CuO maintained consistently higher than that of CuO at the same applied potential, demonstrating the preferential selectivity towards formate during CO2 reduction. Moreover, the limited jformate occurring with CuO at the potential of 1.7 V was alleviated when Prism-CuO was used. This was possibly benefited from the open framework of Prism-CuO that facilitated reactants and electrolytes diffusion to reaction sites along the channels.
Tafel plots were also compared to provide the kinetic insights into the mechanistic pathway (Fig. 4d). Based on the calculation, the Tafel slope declined from 222mV dec 1 (CuO balls) to 179mV dec 1 (Prism-CuO), and this decreased slope value closing to
120mV dec 1 indicated that the boosted kinetics and the ratedetermining step was related to an initial sing-electron transferring to CO2 to form the adsorbed 5tgb CO2 e. Tafel plot for formate varied with varieties and structures of catalyst. Compared to the previous reported Cu-based catalyst (Qiao et al., 2015; Huan et al., 2016; Zhao et al., 2017a), the Tafel slope of Prism-CuO was moderate, indicating the energetic activity towards CO2-to-formate conversion.
It has been reported that the reaction mechanism and the ratedetermining step of CO2 reduction were related to the structure of catalyst because the electrosorption of intermediates took place at certain oxidative potentials on different Cu facets (Min et al., 2016). To reveal the role of unique structure of Prism-CuO, the electrosorption of OH as a surrogate of intermediate was investigated. As shown from CV plots in Fig. 3d, two typical oxidation peaks for the Prism-CuO electrode during anodic scans appeared which was assigned to the low-index facets of Cu (110) at e 0.55 ~ 0.58 V and (111) at e 0.45 ~ 0.50 V, whereas only Cu (111) was detected for electrosorption on CuO micro-ball electrode. This suggested that more low-index facets of Cu were formed during CO2 reduction which would increase the number of metastable active sites. Therefore, the edge- and corner-supported low-coordination facets of Prism-CuO efficiently facilitated electron transfer to the adsorbed CO2 to form CO2 e, and boosted the reaction kinetics in the CO2 electroreduction to formate.
3.4. Electrical field simulation for Prism-CuO catalyst
As described in SEM, the Prism-CuO microspheres were assembled by uneven nano-prisms with various corner angles and edge lengths, the effect of corner angle and edge length on electric field density was simulated with SOMSOL to better understand the highly efficient CO2 activation sites. The field intensities of nanoprisms with different angle range (45 e125 ) and edge length (30e100 nm) were first simulated at the CO2/COOH equilibrium potential of 0.627 V. As shown in Fig. 5a, for these prisms with edge length shorter than 60 nm, the corner had a great impact on electric field intensity. For example, in the case of the edge length of 30 nm and 40 nm, reducing the corner angle from 125 to 45 induced the electric field increasing remarkably by 2.3 and 2.2 times. However, the electric field intensity was depressed and almost maintained constant around the edge longer than 60 nm. On the other hand, when the corner angle was beyond 105 , the electric field value was independent on edge length, indicating that the sharp corner and short edge length of nano-prisms contributed to the higher electric field intensity which benefited CO2 activation. Based on the previous studies that the highest electric field was detected at needle-structured Au followed by rod and particle structure (Liu et al., 2016), the prism-structured CuO with sharp tips was expected to induce higher electric field which concentrated Kþ locally absorbed at reactive sites to reduce the mean square displacement of CO2 relative to the surface as described (Liu et al., 2016). Additionally, more CO2 bonded to HCO3 and Kþ would weaken the CeO, consequently favored to motivate CO2 reduction by accelerating charges transfer process as demonstrated in Fig. 3c.
Furthermore, three different corner angles (45, 85 and 125 ) with the same edge lengths of 30 nm were exampled to further evaluate the variation of electrical field density at different applied potential. In Fig. 5b, clear linearity was built between the applied potential and electrical field. Decreasing the applied cathode potential from 0.2 to 1.8 V led to higher electric field density as the electric fields increased by 9 times. Consistent with the aforementioned results, sharp corner (45 ) always produced the highest electric fields as the valuewas 1.6 and 2.4 times higher compared to that of 85 and 125 . These results pointed out that catalyst
structure, from an aspect of the electric field, played a key role in CO2 electroreduction and guided the direction for efficient catalyst design.

sections.heading: 3.5. Stability of CuxO/Cu for CO2 reduction
sections.text: The stability of electrode for CO2 electroreductionwas evaluated by electrolysing continuously for 20 h (Fu et al., 2016; Guo et al., 2017; Kim et al., 2017; Liu et al., 2017; Qiu et al., 2017). As depicted in Fig. 6a, current density of Prism-CuO electrode at a controlled potential of 1.6 V was almost constant and the average value was ~14.3mA cm 2. The FEformate reached 66.5% at the very first hour, and closed to 63.6% at the end of test with a little fluctuation during the whole electroreduction process, demonstrating the excellent stability of Prism-CuO. After durability test, the electrodewas taken out and dried in vacuum condition for LSV measurement. As shown in Fig. 6b, the LSV scan of electrode after the electrolysis indicated that there was almost no decline in electrochemical activity compared with initial state, further confirming that the nano-prism Prism-CuO was a promising catalyst for CO2 electroreduction.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, we prepared nano-prism assembled CuO microspheres by simple hydrothermal method for efficient electrochemical CO2-formate conversion. The nano-prism structure boosted the kinetic activity of catalyst as the overpotential for formate was ~200mV. Meanwhile, the maximum FEformate reached 65.1% which outperformed most of the reported OD-Cu catalysts but with lower catalyst loading, and the FEformate could be
maintained consistent during 20 h of electrolysis. This better electrochemical performance was attributed to the unique nano-prism features (corners and edges) which increased abundant active reaction sites and higher electric field intensity for CO2 adsorption ant its protonation.

The increased consumption of fossil fuels and the associated emission of CO2 into the atmosphere have caused severe energy crisis and global warming (Hall-Spencer et al., 2008; Davis et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2014).

A promising and attractive route is to electrochemically reduce CO2 into carbon-based value-added chemicals like carbon monoxide, hydrocarbon, carboxylic acid, alcohols, and aldehydes by controlling multiple proton and electron transfer steps (Kuhl et al., 2012).

Among all the possible products, formate (HCOO ) or formic acid (HCOOH) is desired owing to their broad application in fuel cells, H2 storage material, syngas conversion, and other industrial feedstock (Zhang et al., 2017).
The strategy essentially involves catalyzing the reaction by means of a homogeneous or heterogeneous catalyst (Costentin et al., 2013).
